block.p: John Olerud's two-run single snapped a fifth-inning tie yesterday and the Seattle Mariners went on to a 6-3 victory over the struggling Tampa Bay Devil Rays, who have lost 11 of their last 13 games.

Brett Tomko (3-2) allowed three hits in five-plus innings, and the visiting Mariners got two run-scoring singles from Mark McLemore to win for the second straight time after beginning a six-game road trip with three losses at Baltimore.

Brett Tomko (3-2) allowed three hits in five-plus innings, and the visiting Mariners got two run-scoring singles from Mark McLemore to win for the second straight time after beginning a six-game road trip with three losses at Baltimore.
Kazuhiro Sasaki pitched the ninth for his sixth save in seven opportunities. Five Seattle pitchers combined on the four-hitter.
Tampa Bay (15-32) has dropped eight series in a row and has the worst record in the major leagues.
TIGERS 4, BLUE JAYS 3: Deivi Cruz stroked a run-scoring single in the ninth inning to lift host Detroit.
Doug Brocail (2-3) pitched the last one and two-thirds innings for the victory, holding the Blue Jays hitless after relieving Hideo Nomo.
Paul Quantrill (0-2) walked Brad Ausmus to start the Tigers' ninth. Ausmus moved up on a sacrifice bunt by Jose Macias and scored on Cruz's single to right.
Dean Palmer hit a two-run homer for Detroit.

TWINS 10, RANGERS 5: Corey Koskie hit a bases-loaded triple, and Butch Huskey added a two-run double for host Minnesota, which lost all 12 games to Texas last season but has won four of the five games played between the two teams this year.
Joe Mays (2-6) won for the first time since May 3, and Midre Cummings and Cristian Guzman homered for Minnesota, which picked up its 12th comeback victory of the season.
Ruben Mateo hit a two-run homer and David Segui had three runs batted in for the Rangers, who fell to 2-3 on their current nine-game road trip.
WHITE SOX 14, INDIANS 3: Jose Valentin drove in a career-high six runs for host Chicago and fell a single shy of becoming the first American League player to hit for the cycle twice in one season.
Valentin hit a two-run homer in the first inning, a bases-loaded triple in the second and an R.B.I. double in the third.
The White Sox, who led by 14-0 after seven innings, opened a two-and-a-half-game lead over the Indians in the A.L. Central. Cleveland lost for the fourth time in five games.
Carlos Lee homered and drove in three runs, Frank Thomas hit two R.B.I. doubles and Magglio Ordonez drove in two runs with two singles for Chicago.
ATHLETICS 4, ORIOLES 0: Tim Hudson allowed one hit over seven and one-third innings for his fifth straight victory as Oakland ended host Baltimore's four-game winning streak.
The lone hit off Hudson was a fifth-inning single by Will Clark. The sinking liner to center popped out of the glove of a diving Terrence Long.
Hudson (6-2) walked four and struck out five. He was lifted after issuing a one-out walk to Greg Myers in the eighth.
Hudson allowed only two balls out of the infield and permitted only one runner past second base in improving to 5-0 over his last six starts.

ROYALS 6, ANGELS 5: Dave McCarty hit a game-tying, two-run homer in the ninth inning, and Carlos Beltran scored the winning run in the 10th on a sacrifice fly just past first base as Kansas City beat host Anaheim.
The Royals, who rallied from a 5-3 deficit in the ninth against Troy Percival, won for the 12th time this season in their final at-bat.
Dan Reichert (3-3) pitched two hitless innings for the victory.
Percival, who leads the A.L. with 14 saves, blew his third chance of the season in the ninth.
